Blurb
Educational Aims
Upon completion of this module, students will be able to:

1. Understand the basic principles of microbial genomics and the tools and technologies used in the study of microbial genomics.

2. Understand the principles of comparative genomics and be able to use comparative genomics tools to study the evolution.

3. Understand the principles of microbial evolution, including the mechanisms of genetic variation, natural selection, and genetic drift, in the context of biotic and abiotic pressures.

4. Understand the evolution of pathogenic and symbiotic lifestyles with host and in microbial communities, including the genetic mechanisms underlying these relationships.

5. Analyse and interpret genomic data to address questions related to microbial evolution and ecology, with a focus on pathogenic and symbiotic relationships with host and microbial communities.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide a comprehensive introduction to genomics and evolution of microbes, with a particular focus on how microbes evolve in response to biotic and abiotic pressure. The module will cover the principles of microbial genomics, comparative genomics, and microbial evolution, with a specific emphasis on the evolution of pathogenic and symbiotic lifestyles with host and in microbial communities. The importance and use of genomics and bioinformatics in understanding the genetic and mechanisms of evolution will be a key theme. The module will use in person lecture, tutorials and workshops, support with recorded content and suggested reading. Assessment is via practical with report and data handling paper.
Outline Syllabus
This module will cover the following topics:

1. Introduction to microbial genomics
• Principles of DNA sequencing and genome assembly
• Genomic annotation and analysis tools
• Metagenomics and functional genomics

2. Comparative genomics
•Genome evolution and synteny
• Phylogenetics and phylogenomics
• Horizontal gene transfer and gene duplication

3. Microbial evolution
• Mechanisms of genetic variation
• Natural selection and adaptation
• Genetic drift and neutral evolution
• Evolution in response to biotic and abiotic pressures

4. Evolution of pathogenic and symbiotic lifestyles
• Host-pathogen interactions and the evolution of virulence
• Symbiotic relationships with host and microbial communities
• Genetic mechanisms underlying pathogenic and symbiotic lifestyles

5. Genomics and bioinformatics in understanding microbial evolution
• Comparative genomics and the study of microbial evolution
• Genomics and bioinformatics tools for studying pathogenic and symbiotic relationships
• Limitations of genomics and bioinformatics in studying microbial evolution and ecology
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The module will utilise lectures, practical/workshops and tutorials. There will be 15 workshops/lectures and 2 practical/workshops. An average week would be 1 50 minute lecture and a 50 min tutorial. Practical/workshops will be linked to the lectures. For tutorials students will be provided with pre-set work/papers for discussion to supplement learning and understanding of the content of the preceding lectures. They will also build to the final assessment giving the students experience in data interpretation and understanding.

Active-learning: Through tutorials and pre-session online study assignments and workshops students will be provided a platform to synthesise and critically evaluate issues in greater depth. Students will be encouraged, in both in the classroom environment and in the VLE, to discuss the course content and online study assignments and share with each other their values and perspectives.

Digital Fluency: All materials and content will be made available on the VLE and will improve digital fluency.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to teaching material, further reading and online discussion boards online. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussion and learning task for lectures and workshops.

Self-directed learning will include reading selected additional content provided by the lecturers to supplement the lecture content, preparation for workshops and both assimilating and integrating content from across the module.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed by two assessments:

Assessment 1: Practical report. Building on the practical sessions in the producing a lab report 1500, to include figure and analysis of data. This is an authentic way to assess scientific knowledge and understanding and is an important employability skill. This will contribute 60% of the module mark. Scientific report writing and communication are highly authentic skills.

Assessment 2: Data handling examination. The assessment will be for 1.5 hours in total. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). Handing, analysing, interpreting and describing scientific data is highly authentic and an important graduate skill which enhances digital fluency. This will contribute 40% of the module mark.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data may differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Digital Fluency: All materials and content will be made available on the VLE and will improve digital fluency.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to teaching material, further reading and online discussion boards online. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussion and learning task for lectures and workshops.

Self-directed learning will include reading selected additional content provided by the lecturers to supplement the lecture content, preparation for workshops and both assimilating and integrating content from across the module.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed by two assessments:

Assessment 1: Practical report. Building on the practical sessions in the producing a lab report 1500, to include figure and analysis of data. This is an authentic way to assess scientific knowledge and understanding and is an important employability skill. This will contribute 60% of the module mark. Scientific report writing and communication are highly authentic skills.

Assessment 2: Data handling examination. The assessment will be for 1.5 hours in total. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). Handing, analysing, interpreting and describing scientific data is highly authentic and an important graduate skill which enhances digital fluency. This will contribute 40% of the module mark.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data may differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Blurb
Educational Aims
Upon completion of this module, students will be able to:

1. Understand the basic principles of microbial genomics and the tools and technologies used in the study of microbial genomics.

2. Understand the principles of comparative genomics and be able to use comparative genomics tools to study the evolution.

3. Understand the principles of microbial evolution, including the mechanisms of genetic variation, natural selection, and genetic drift, in the context of biotic and abiotic pressures.

4. Understand the evolution of pathogenic and symbiotic lifestyles with host and in microbial communities, including the genetic mechanisms underlying these relationships.

5. Analyse and interpret genomic data to address questions related to microbial evolution and ecology, with a focus on pathogenic and symbiotic relationships with host and microbial communities.
Marketing Module Synopsis
The aim of this module is to provide a comprehensive introduction to genomics and evolution of microbes, with a particular focus on how microbes evolve in response to biotic and abiotic pressure. The module will cover the principles of microbial genomics, comparative genomics, and microbial evolution, with a specific emphasis on the evolution of pathogenic and symbiotic lifestyles with host and in microbial communities. The importance and use of genomics and bioinformatics in understanding the genetic and mechanisms of evolution will be a key theme. The module will use in person lecture, tutorials and workshops, support with recorded content and suggested reading. Assessment is via practical with report and data handling paper.
Outline Syllabus
This module will cover the following topics:

1. Introduction to microbial genomics
• Principles of DNA sequencing and genome assembly
• Genomic annotation and analysis tools
• Metagenomics and functional genomics

2. Comparative genomics
•Genome evolution and synteny
• Phylogenetics and phylogenomics
• Horizontal gene transfer and gene duplication

3. Microbial evolution
• Mechanisms of genetic variation
• Natural selection and adaptation
• Genetic drift and neutral evolution
• Evolution in response to biotic and abiotic pressures

4. Evolution of pathogenic and symbiotic lifestyles
• Host-pathogen interactions and the evolution of virulence
• Symbiotic relationships with host and microbial communities
• Genetic mechanisms underlying pathogenic and symbiotic lifestyles

5. Genomics and bioinformatics in understanding microbial evolution
• Comparative genomics and the study of microbial evolution
• Genomics and bioinformatics tools for studying pathogenic and symbiotic relationships
• Limitations of genomics and bioinformatics in studying microbial evolution and ecology
Teaching and Learning Methods
Learning and teaching throughout this module is designed and delivered by research-active scientists to ensure that teaching is informed by the latest research and best evidence (Research-connected teaching, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The module will utilise lectures, practical/workshops and tutorials. There will be 15 workshops/lectures and 2 practical/workshops. An average week would be 1 50 minute lecture and a 50 min tutorial. Practical/workshops will be linked to the lectures. For tutorials students will be provided with pre-set work/papers for discussion to supplement learning and understanding of the content of the preceding lectures. They will also build to the final assessment giving the students experience in data interpretation and understanding.

Active-learning: Through tutorials and pre-session online study assignments and workshops students will be provided a platform to synthesise and critically evaluate issues in greater depth. Students will be encouraged, in both in the classroom environment and in the VLE, to discuss the course content and online study assignments and share with each other their values and perspectives.

Digital Fluency: All materials and content will be made available on the VLE and will improve digital fluency.

Inclusivity: Students will have access to teaching material, further reading and online discussion boards online. Lectures will be recorded to enable students to access materials asynchronously.

Confidence: Students will be encouraged and supported to make full contributions to discussion and learning task for lectures and workshops.

Self-directed learning will include reading selected additional content provided by the lecturers to supplement the lecture content, preparation for workshops and both assimilating and integrating content from across the module.

In exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
The module will be assessed by two assessments:

Assessment 1: Practical report. Building on the practical sessions in the producing a lab report 1500, to include figure and analysis of data. This is an authentic way to assess scientific knowledge and understanding and is an important employability skill. This will contribute 60% of the module mark. Scientific report writing and communication are highly authentic skills.

Assessment 2: Data handling examination. The assessment will be for 1.5 hours in total. The number of questions will be determined based on the complexity of the questions (i.e. reading time and information required). Handing, analysing, interpreting and describing scientific data is highly authentic and an important graduate skill which enhances digital fluency. This will contribute 40% of the module mark.

Pass mark for all assessments is 40%. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission of all assessments. Assessments are anonymous.

Reassessment will use the same format but the topic or data may differ. Mark will be capped at 40%. This will take place in the normal reassessment window. Standard UoL penalty applies for late submission.

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
